newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu says settlers will never leave Hebron.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu says settlers will never leave Hebron.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu promised right-wing supporters on Thursday that Jewish settlers would never be forced to leave the West Bank town of Hebron.
"The Jewish community in Hebron will not be uprooted -- not now, not tomorrow, never," he said in a speech to members of the National Relgious Party, a key partner in his coalition government.

Around 400 Jewish settlers live among 100,000 Palestinians in Hebron, the last of seven West Bank towns Israel's previous Labour-led government promised a year ago to hand over for Palestinian self-rule.

Under a landmark 1993 Israel-PLO interim deal, the future of Hebron settlers and 130,000 other Jews living in the West Bank and Gaza -- which Israel captured in the 1967 war -- will be determined in talks on a final peace agreement to be reached by 1999.

Netanyhau opposed the 1993 deal that launched Palestinian self-rule but has vowed to withdraw troops from parts of Hebron once Palestinians agree to modifications aimed at better safeguarding settlers in the town.
The two sides have failed in four weeks of intensive talks to agree on terms for the withdrawal.
Israel has accused Palestinian President Yasser Arafat of stalling to rally international pressure against Israel. Palestinians say Israel wants to renege on its commitments.
More than two million Palestinians live in the West Bank and Gaza where the PLO hopes to establish an independent state.
